description: From Middle English communion, from Old French comunion, from Ecclesiastical Latin commūniō (“communion”), from Latin commūnis.

entries.meaning: A joining together of minds or spirits; a mental connection.

examples: It is with the day of her first communion that this narrative of mine begins.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) A form of ecclesiastical unity between the Roman Church and another, so that the latter is considered part of the former.
